- **这一段就是整个熟的核心了。意思就是说，如果说之前在ant里面，一个网络是不做任何区分的一个平面的网络。在这本书里。拉图尔想做的就是在连接点处看到他连的东西，他不同的志向。能够看到一个网络不再是一个平平的。抽象的点的集合，而是把每个点看成执行上完全不同的东西，每一个都是有自己的存在模式。所以呢就是从网络。到借此介词比如说between，from，to，on，to，其实经常就是描述两种不同的关系。比如说我有时候为什么用印，有时候为什么用昂，全都是因为我考虑关系两侧是不同东西，他们能够用什么样的方式联系起来？比如说我。住在一个地方，我站在什么上面？啊，我和谁一起？等等。董志，他们是描述的是不同质性的物体的关系。**

**也正是因为这样，这就构成了拉图尔本书的结构上或者说方法上的核心就是通过在跨越和把自身变成他者，他者化的过程中。看到。不同的存在模式。通过这样的方式来弥补他之前的过错。给现代性。标志了现代人或者现代人相信他们拥有的。很多的现代存在模式。把他们勾勒出来。同时呢，对他们的勾勒也是用一种类似于结构性我，但我觉得更像是架构性的理解。**

## 1925. Second test: does the
etection of one mode
all
> Second test: does the  etection of one mode  allow us to respect  the other modes? If, on the contrary, this first test succeeds, at  least partially, if readers, profiting from the gap our  method has established between the thread of experi- ence and its institutional rendering, begin to register  documents parallel to mine, concerning one mode or  several, we can go on to the second test: that of the comparison between  modes. Do we gain in quality by crossing several ontological templates in  order to evaluate, little by little, what is distinctive about each one? And,  an even more daunting subtest: do we gain in verisimilitude by treating  all the modes at once in such a move of envelopment? I am well aware that I passed over each mode too quickly, and that  each crossing would require volumes of erudition, even if the modes and  crossings are more fully developed in the digital environment that accom- panies this text. But it would be unfair to ask me to go more deeply into  each domain, each institution, each period, each counter-move of one  mode on another, at the level of detail required by specialists. So this is not  the way this inquiry asks to be judged: the only usable criterion is whether  the light shed on a given mode makes it possible, through successive cross- ings, to reinstitute the other modes. Specialists obviously don’t have to ask  themselves this question. The anthropologist does. This is an operation that the Moderns have never attempted, in my opinion, and their failure  to do so has led them to multiply their misunderstandings about the other  collectives, first of all, but also about themselves. They were too busy  forging ahead; they never consented to look at themselves straight on  and acknowledge all their trump cards. Strangely enough, in the history  of anthropology, there haven’t been any “first contacts” with the Whites.  The mythical stage that I propose to set is thus this one: by unfolding their entire set of values all at once, do we do them justice at last? I know perfectly well that the attempt is far-fetched. But still, if you were to inherit from a relative who was both wealthy and eccentric, who  had died intestate, wouldn’t you try to draw up a list of all his properties  and all his papers? Since we have never been modern and never will be,  we still really need to know what has happened, no? And another factor  justifies being somewhat vague on details so as to have a clearer view of the whole: the fact that our goal is to make the collectives more readily  comparable while using a system of coordinates different from those  §3-Conclusion• 478

第一个部分是发现形容词。
> our groups would really correspond: adjective—the phenome- non, which is to say: evident being as clear manifestation, with  instantaneous quale at the limit, freed from all substantial ties;  noun—identical and permanent being, with eternity at the  limit, the substance that abides; verb—real being as event, as  action, as fact, with, at the limit, the sufficiency of the act that  posits itself and defines itself through its force, and not (like  the phenomenon) through its qualitative essence; finally, prep- ositions, conjunctions, articles—all that is real as correlative or  completive determination, which is called synapse.

> `(SouDifferent15|181); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[SouDifferent15]] Souriau - 2015 - The Different Modes of Existence.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:13:47`

- **所以在发现存在模式的过程中，如果用语言学来比你的话。一共有四个部分。**

**第一个部分是发现形容词。形容词形容词就是那些明确的展现出来的存在者。形容词的存在的界限。就是他的属性。**

**第二个就是名词。也就是同一的和永恒的存在。名词的界限是永恒。也就是那种持存的。**

**第三个是动词。也就是作为事件的真正存在。作为行动。作为事实。这是他的存在的边界。使其成为存在的。不是他的不是他的不是他内容。而是他的动作的效果。**

**最后的。是各种的连接词和冠词。也就是那些作为对应物的。和补充决定物的存在。他们都叫做接触点（synapse）。**

## 2175. My argument is that even while the concept of law
> My argument is that even while the concept of law is subject to expansion and revision, the very word, and hence the concept also, remains tainted by its political and theological origins. An interest in order rather than law could imply far-reaching changes in our conception of science. Most directly, it would imply a shift in the focus of scientific inquiry from the pursuit of the unified laws of nature to an interest in the multiple and varied kinds of order actually expressed in nature. The former focus has historically described physics better than biology; a focus on order might look more to the biological sciences than to physics for its model. And within both physics and biology, priorities might be expected to shift away from hierarchical models of simple, relatively static systems toward more global and interactive models of complex dynamic systems.

## 2189. The general argument is essentially the same as th
> The general argument is essentially the same as that which I made against the notion of "a different science," in the introduction to part 3. To the extent that science is defined by its past and present practitioners, anyone who aspires to membership in that community must conform to its existing code. As a consequence, the inclusion of new members, even from a radically different culture, cannot induce immediate or direct change. To be a successful scientist, one must first be adequately socialized. For this reason, it is unreasonable to expect a sharp differentiation between women scientists and their male colleagues, and indeed, most women scientists would be appalled by such a suggestion.
>
> `(KelReflections96|348); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[KelReflections96]] Keller - 1996 - Reflections on gender and science.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:13:51`

## 2260. M E A N I N G F U L  I N E F F I C I E N C I E S

> M E A N I N G F U L  I N E F F I C I E N C I E S 8 the work of designers, and they are thoughtfully, and often quietly,  innovating the shape of civic life. This book draws attention to these practices and encourages a  rethinking of how innovation within public- serving organizations is  understood, applied, and sought after. As more and more technolo- gies are applied to the ins and outs of civic life, from voting to con- sultation with elected officials, to advocating for local change, we  remain enthusiastic about the possibilities of enhanced efficiency.  But we are confident that unchecked efficiency can be damaging for  public- serving organizations to achieve their desired goals, specifi- cally when they require trust and care from the publics they serve. DESIGN Design scholar Chris LeDantec (2016) uses the term “social de- sign” to describe the process of designing technologies with people  who become invested in the outcomes. What we call civic design  is social, as LeDantec describes it, but it also refers to the intended  outcome of the design process— the creation of civic spaces. The  practitioners we call civic designers are creating opportunities  to interact, form alliances, generate shared interest, and care for  matters of public concern. There are a growing number of these  practitioners in the United States and beyond. Political philosopher  Peter Levine in his book We Are the Ones We Have Been Waiting For  (2015) documents this growth in the United States. He calls for a  daylighting of the 1 million most active citizens who are pursuing  local, deliberative, and novel approaches to civic life into a self-  conscious civic renewal movement. Levine’s book is a smart and  optimistic articulation of a contemporary moment where there is  an emergent commitment to recognizing and supporting a plurality

- **标题比较多义的一本书：Against the grain = 反对标准，依赖谷物，反对谷物。书里的几个意思都有。这本是JS作为一个“业余爱好者”来跨界到考古、古代史、人类学的领域，看公元前4000-2000年间"prestate"的发展。他的主要意思就是（正如可以预料的那样），State（稳定的依赖农耕，尤其依赖谷物，因为谷物方便保存、容易计量和征税、卡路里含量不低）和Prestate（相对稳定的小聚落）和Nonstate（流动的游牧、采食）三者之间不是线性的关系。不是从游牧到农耕的“文明进化”，而是nonstate被state吸纳和剥削，经过危机解体以后再度成为分散的nonstate，之后再被吸纳的反复过程。所以很多相应的state/nonstate的特点，例如文字、例如农耕技术等等都不是专属于某一种组织形式，而是互相吸纳，并行发展。章节主要写了在转换过程中带来的影响，例如土地的盐化，聚集造成导致的传染病，对蛮人概念的形成等等。基本点还是JS的老观点，State就像疾病一样，造成从人的营养、到族群健康、到环境的种种危机，很多方便并不如我们视为落后和原始的nonstate状态。我们之所以有今天的观点有不少是来自于由state书写的历史记录。在生态上，state和附属于state的蛮人nonstate也是共生(symbiotic)的互相以来，大多数时候稳定有是不稳定的（蛮族入关etc）关系。读的时候就为JS捏一把汗，后来看了下对他的批评很多就是针对一些他对他所依赖的考古的二手材料的错误理解，例如在苏美尔文明早期谷物和其他食物相比可能没有那么的重要。但正因为他姿态放得比较低（其实也是比较高，这种有民科嫌疑的书不是成名的学者是不可能被出版的），理论线条比较粗，也比较好用，例如sedentism, stateness这些，评价总体来说还算不错。我的感觉也是里面讲到state-formation的分析的时候才是他的强项，讲到依赖别人的二手文献的古文明的部分就如履薄冰。整体尚可。**

## 2358. "Whatever the reasons for the growing reliance on
> "Whatever the reasons for the growing reliance on do­ mesticated grains and animals for subsistence, it represented  a qualitative change in landscape modification. The cultivars  were transformed ; the livestock was transformed ; the soils and  fodder they depended on were transformed ; and, not least,  omo sapiens was transformed. Here the term "domestica­ tion" - from "domus," or household - needs to be taken rather  literally. The domus was a unique and unprecedented con­ centration of tilled fields, seed and grain stores, people, and  domestic animals, all coevolving with consequences no one  could have possibly foreseen. Just as important, the domus  as a module of evolution was irresistibly attractive to literally thousands of uninvited hangers-on who thrived in its little  ecosystem. At the top of the heap were the so-called com­ mensals: sparrows, mice, rats, crows, and (quasi-invited) dogs,  pigs, and cats for which this new Ark was a veritable feedlot.  Each of these commensals in turn brought along its own train  of microparasites - fleas, ticks, leeches, mosquitoes, lice, and  mites -as well as their predators ; the dogs and cats were there  in large part for the mice, rats, and sparrows. Not a single  critter emerged from its sojourn at the late-Neolithic multi­ species resettlement camp unaffected.

## 2389. The entire exercise in early state formation is on
> The entire exercise in early state formation is one of standardization and abstraction required to deal with units of  labor, grain, land, and rations. Essential to that standardiza­ tion is the very invention of a standard nomenclature, through  writing, of all the essential categories -receipts, work orders,  labor dues, and so on. The creation and imposition of a writ­ ten code throughout the city-state replaced vernacular judg­ ments and was itself a distance-demolishing technology that  held sway throughout the small realm. Labor standards were  developed for such tasks as ploughing, harrowing, or sowing.  Something like "work points" were created, showing credits  and debits in work assignments. Standards of classification  and quality were specified for fish, oil , and textiles -which  ere differentiated by weight and mesh. Livestock, slaves, and  laborers were classified by gender and age. In embryonic form,  the vital statistics of an appropriating state aiming to extract  as much value as possible from its land and people is already in  vidence. How formidable this regimentation looked on the  ground is another matter.
>

## 2548. 行为学的效用观念(在早期奥国学派经济学家的用语中为“主观的使用价
值”，必须与工艺学的效用观念(在
> 行为学的效用观念(在早期奥国学派经济学家的用语中为“主观的使用价 值”，必须与工艺学的效用观念(在上述经济学家的用语中为“客观的使用价 值")严格区分。客观意义的使用价值.是指一物与它能使发生的效果之间的  关系。例如,人们说到煤的“热值”或“热力”的时候，所指的就是客观的使用价  值。主观的使用价值往往与真正的客观使用价值无关。有些事物之有主观的  用价值,是因为人们误信它们有发生他所想望的效果的能力。相反地，有些  事物确能发生所想望的效果，但人们不认为它们有使用价值，这是因为他们不  知道这个事实。
>
> `(VXiaRenDe15|149); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[VXiaRenDe15]] Von Mises, 夏道平 - 2015 - 人的行为 = Human action - a treatise on economics.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:14:17`

> This book analyses workers’ collective action at various sites of production primarily  in China, India, Honduras, and United States, and secondarily in Vietnam, Cambodia,  Bangladesh, and Indonesia. It observes how this internal logic plays out for labour  who are testing the limits of the social order, stretching it until the seams show, and  making it possible for bosses to come to the proverbial table, hat in hand, to hash out  agreements with those who assemble their goods. By examining the most valorized parts  of underdeveloped sectors, one can see where capital is going and how it is getting there.  The findings contribute to ongoing strategies to bolster workers’ bargaining power in  sectors plagued by poverty, powerlessness, and perilous workplaces. Indeed, with these  changes in global capitalism and a capable labour movement, there’s hope yet that workers  may close the gap.

## 2679. 一个比较乐观的左派的政治经济学分析，针对的是服装制造业的血汗工厂现象。出发点是与其他sector（例
> onopsony Capitalism
>
> `(KAMonopsony20|2); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[KAMonopsony20]] Kumar, Ashok - 2020 - Monopsony Capitalism - Power and Production in the Twilight of the Sweatshop Age.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:14:29`

- **一个比较乐观的左派的政治经济学分析，针对的是服装制造业的血汗工厂现象。出发点是与其他sector（例如汽车制造业）相比，服装业产业升级十分缓慢，现在全球范围血汗工厂的现象仍然普遍。原因自然是资本为了保持利润率，像管制和成本较少的地区转移（所谓资本的spatial fix），同时大资本在竞争中胜出后，会使买入方越来越少，让市场变成买方垄断市场(monopsony)，代工厂为了获得少数几个大公司（例如耐克阿迪这些）的订单，不得不进行激烈竞争，让劳工权益进一步下降。总而言之，资本的转移和买方垄断，使得血汗工厂得以延续。作者的新意在于他观察各国，如印度孟加拉中等等地近些年的劳工运动，发现在买方市场的情况下，本地的代工厂会在竞争过后也变得“垄断”。一个规模庞大、技术规格高的代工厂让代工市场的entry of barrier变高，使得大买入方没有其他竞争者可以选，由此给代工厂本身，和代工厂的工人提供了谈判的筹码，因为他们现在具有了更高的“空间固化性”（也就是资本由于受到市场或者法规的限制，无法再自由地转移到更容易剥削的地区的时候）。中国的例子是14年在广东的台商裕元工厂针对缺交社保的protest，最后以劳方得到部分满足告终。以此为例，作者的意思是，让子弹再飞一会儿，资本在80年代去管制化以来获得的资本灵活性在逐渐减弱，边缘地区的谈判筹码在加强。服装业作为血汗工厂的重灾区在未来有可能改善，甚至消失。**

> organizing methods. Within the garment sector, the ILGWU made gains despite  its vertical disintegration. The jobber was responsible  for designing goods, marketing them to the public, and supplying the fabric  necessary for their construction to contractors. ## 2830. This essay uses simple tools of economic theory to
> This essay uses simple tools of economic theory to analyze interactions between the behavior of some persons and different characteristics of other persons. Although these interactions are emphasized in the contemporary sociological and anthropological literature, and were considered the cornerstone of behavior by several prominent nineteenth-century econo­ mists, they have been largely ignored in the modern economic literature. The central concept of the analysis is “social income,” the sum of a person’s own income (his earnings, etc.) and the monetary value to him  of the relevant characteristics of others, which I call his social environ­ ment. The optimal expenditure of his own income to alter these character­ istics is given by the usual marginal conditions. By using the concept of social income, I can analyze the effect on these expenditures of changes in  different sources of income and in different prices, including the “price”  of the social environment. Perhaps the most important implication is  that a  change in own income alone would tend to cause a relatively  laige change in these expenditures; in other words, the own-income  elasticity of demand for these expenditures would tend to be “large,”  certainly larger than the elasticity resulting from equal percentage changes  in own income and the social environment.
>
> `(BecEconomic76|287); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[BecEconomic76]] Becker - 1976 - The Economic Approach to Human Behavior.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:15:06`

> Such a theory cannot be tested by comparing its "assumptions" directly with "reality." Indeed, there is no meaningful way in which this can be done. Complete "realism" is clearly unattain­ able, and the question whether a theory is realistic "enough" can be settled only by seeing whether it yields predictions that are good enough for the purpose in hand or that are better than predictions from alternative theories. Yet the belief that a theory can be tested by the realism of its assumptions independently of the accuracy of its predictions is widespread and the source of much of the perennial criticism of economic theory as unrealistic. - **重新刊发了阿多诺在40年代讨论“需要”的问题。核心观点是（1）需要是历史产物。(2) 为“需要”背书--例如说看电影是人的天然的审美需要--的“自然驱动”，也是不自然的，也是历史当下生产关系的产物。(3) 由此，左派对“需要”的必然，必然是动态的历史分析，而不是设置一批“真实”的需要，来批判“虚假”的需要。在座的“需要”都是历史。**

**阿多诺这篇其实是为了引出这期的另一个重点，Kenta Tsuda对“去增长”（Degrowth）派的批判。标题叫“一些优质的问题”，但他实际在说去增长派的幼稚。他本人明显是支持Green New Deal的。Green New Deal和Degrowth的区别在于一个需要增长提供的gdp来快速提高能源使用效率和研发可再生能源，而degrowthers正是好找限制”增长”，把环境看成一个全球的负载问题。从目标上来说，两个阵营没什么区别，都关心co2排放问题，分期就在于他们把什么当成主要障碍。degrowthers把“理念”当成主要障碍。认为我们清楚了观念上对增长的依赖等等，就可以接受紧缩"contraction"作为发展目标。例如他们提出我们可以把“需要”(阿多诺要来了)降到最低标准，只保留一些“根本需要”。这个"list of needs“当然就是左派嘲笑的对象了。也是为什么这期要重刊阿多诺。文章其他部分都是对类似“幼稚病”的批评。比较有力度的就是指出当下环境危机的一大来源，就是里根时期应对经济停滞加国际石油危机（因为美国对以色列的支持），所放宽的环境政策。而这些政策经过obama和trump以后，仍然没有被rollback。这就不是“观念”问题，是政治问题。不过作者总体把自己的文章作为一种商榷，毕竟有共同目标，写文章主要希望degrowthers能提出一些切实可行的政治programme出来。**

## 3176. hroughput’. Degrowthers see no escape through clea
> hroughput’. Degrowthers see no escape through cleaner energy or  ore efficient resource use, due to the dynamic known as the ‘Jevons  ebound’.13 In 1865, the English economist William Stanley Jevons  showed that improved efficiency in the combustion of coal counterin- tuitively resulted in accel erated depletion of coal supplies: the efficiency  improvement initially reduced demand for coal—less coal needed per  unit of mechanical work. But due to the resulting change in price, con- sumers responded by demanding more mechanical work (new steam  engines became cost-effective for a wider range of applications) and thus  more coal. Degrowthers generalize the Jevons-rebound effect from the  19th-century coal market to the civilizational use of physical materials  considered in aggregate.14 Technological progress may ren der resource  use more efficient—the same work or consumption can be generated  from fewer resources—but, degrowthers posit, all efficiency gains are  offset by expansions in scale. The macro-level rebound effect, they claim,  quashes hopes of technological advances that would reduce material  throughput to a sustainable level without a policy of downsizing.
>
> `(KenNaive21|5); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[KenNaive21]] Kenta Tsuda - 2021 - Naive Questions on Degrowth.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:15:37`

> In analyzing workplace governance regimes, I  start with Robert Dahl’s  framework for evaluating the conditions that make democracy possible,  in which he highlighted two dimensions:  inclusion and contestation. The  first refers to the extent to which the population is entitled to participate  in democratic processes, while the second refers to the openness of these  processes to competition. Dahl submitted that no existing regime could be  considered fully democratic, but he proposed that democratic claims could  best be evaluated by considering these two conditions. Although he used
>
> `(AndDisenfranchised19|24); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[AndDisenfranchised19]] Andreas - 2019 - Disenfranchised - The Rise and Fall of Industrial Citizenship in China.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:15:44`

## 3282. In adapting Dahl’s basic framework, I have chosen
> In adapting Dahl’s basic framework, I have chosen to use the concepts cit- izenship and autonomy because they help elucidate the conditions necessary  for democratic participation in workplace governance. The first condition,  citizenship, connotes inclusion as it recognizes the elemental qualification  that only members of an organization are accorded rights to participate in  democratic decision- making within that organization. This is true of any  organization, from small voluntary associations to sovereign states, and it  is certainly true of workplaces. When Dahl turned his attention to democ- racy in the workplace, he pointed out that this would entail transforming  “employees from corporate subjects to citizens of the enterprise.”10 The second condition, autonomy, is the fundamental requirement for con- testation as only those who enjoy autonomy are in a position to engage in  contestation. Its meaning, however, is broader. Autonomy is commonly de- fined as capacity for self- governance; for my purposes, it refers to the capacity  for independent action at multiple levels, from shop- floor self- management  to collective action independent of enterprise and state authorities. When  individuals manage their own work, this does not necessarily involve contes- tation, but even autonomy at this basic level is absent in despotic systems of  industrial relations, in which even the most minute activities are controlled  by factory authorities. At higher levels, the meaning of autonomy becomes  more collective, more political, and more contentious, including the right to  organize to change policies or capture positions of power.
>

## 3285. Over the course of its first decade in power, the
> Over the course of its first decade in power, the CCP completely transformed  Chinese factories, creating a system of industrial relations that would remain  in place for the next four decades. Employment, which had been highly  precarious, became much more stable, and an increasingly comprehensive  system of workplace- based welfare provision was established. Moreover,  the new regime aggressively enlisted workers to take part in factory affairs,  mobilizing them to participate in campaigns that undermined and even- tually displaced the incumbent owners and managers. Workers enthusi- astically took part in these campaigns, which featured new structures for  employee participation, and many were promoted to positions of respon- sibility. These changes laid the foundations for a strong system of indus- trial citizenship. The possibility of developing truly democratic institutions,  however, was curtailed by the refusal of party leaders to accept autonomous  collective activity by workers or even by the union organization that oper- ated under party auspices.
>

## 3289. While in previous chapters, I have developed a com
> While in previous chapters, I have developed a common historical nar- rative of the entire country, that endeavor— always challenging— becomes  impossible for this period. During the initial months of the Cultural  Revolution, recounted in Chapter 5, events in factories across the country  followed a trajectory that was fairly similar and produced rebel and con- servative camps that looked very much alike in different cities. That  changed, however, after rebel groups attempted to seize power in January  1967. Subsequent conflicts over who was to be named to new revolutionary  committees caused the rebel movement to fracture and led to complex  and shifting alliances involving contending mass organizations, veteran  cadres, and military officers, which propelled provinces on different paths. > Between 1972 and 1976, China was swept by alternating political winds,  shifting abruptly in favor of the administrative faction and then in favor of  the radical faction, with the direction modulated by Mao. Under the banner of the “Four Modernizations,” Zhou  Enlai and Deng Xiaoping decried the economic disruptions caused by po- litical disorder and factionalism and called for renewed efforts to upgrade  and rationalize industrial production and strengthen the oversight and  coordination provided by industrial ministries. ## 3296. The last years of the Mao era were hardly a period
> The last years of the Mao era were hardly a period of economic collapse, as is often suggested. During this period, despite the upheavals of the Cultural  Revolution, China continued to experience impressive industrial growth.  From 1965 through 1978, industrial production grew by an average of 10.2%  a year, down somewhat from the 12.3% annual rate of the 1952– 1965 pe- riod but significantly outpacing Japan during the same period.79 Industrial  employment more than tripled, increasing from about 18 million to more  than 67 million, which by this time included over 17 million people who  worked in small commune and brigade factories.80 The extremely rapid rate  of job growth was a result of state policies that continued to prioritize full  employment over labor productivity. This industrial expansion took place  in a largely autarkic environment (with little foreign aid, investment, or  trade), in which economic decision- making was much more decentralized  than in the past, the party was in disarray, and party leadership was split be- tween contending factions.
>

## 3314. One key goal was to downgrade the power of the fac
> One key goal was to downgrade the power of the factory party organiza- tion and enhance the power of the factory director. As noted in Chapter 3,  the system of industrial governance established by the CCP in the 1950s  had distinguished between zhengwu (“political affairs”), which was the re- sponsibility of the party organization, and yewu (“business” or “production  affairs”), which was the responsibility of the management hierarchy. The  party had insisted on the primacy of zhengwu; as a result, the factory party  committee made all key decisions, and the most powerful individual was  the party secretary rather than the factory director (who usually served as  the deputy party secretary). By the mid- 1980s, Deng Xiaoping and his allies  were determined to put more power in the hands of the factory director in  order to prioritize production and profit, rather than the political and social  concerns that were the responsibility of the party committee.

## 3319. During this period, Chinese factories were moving
> During this period, Chinese factories were moving in contradictory  directions. On the one hand, by the end of the decade industrial work  units had evolved into even more elaborate “small societies” composed of  many subunits that, in addition to producing goods, provided a range jobs  and services for a growing community of employees and their families. ## 3325. The Labor Law, which guided the second conversion,
> The Labor Law, which guided the second conversion, dealt with the most  traumatic part of restructuring— the transformation of the workforce. In the  ensuing years, tens of millions of workers, considered redundant, were laid  off. Restructuring, however, not only required cutting jobs but also involved  fundamentally changing the relationship between workers and enterprises.  CCP leaders decided that as part of restructuring state enterprises should  formally terminate relations with all of their staff in exchange for compen- sation based on how long they had been working, a process called maiduan  gongling (买断工龄, “buying out years of service”). The term maiduan com- bined characters meaning “to buy” and “to sever.”

## 3326. It is significant that all workers were required t
> It is significant that all workers were required to maiduan, not only to  those who were laid off but also to those who continued working. As was  made abundantly clear in the press, maiduan was designed to signal a fun- damental change in workers’ status, from work unit members to contract  employees. The intent was to free the newly corporatized enterprises from  the encumbrances that had tied work units to their members. These in- cluded not only economic obligations but also the complex social and polit- ical relationships and mutual expectations that had been cultivated within  work units. For decades, workers had been told that they were masters of  the factory and that they should consider the factory to be their home. Now,  the CCP was intent on undoing these expectations, and it decided to do  so in dramatic fashion. Maiduan was designed to put an unequivocal end  to the entitlements and rights that work unit members had enjoyed, with  money offered to sweeten the bitterness. Promising maiduan money to all  employees, including those who remained working, created a huge finan- cial obligation for the companies and the government, but party leaders  evidently considered this to be a necessary cost in order to fundamentally  change the relationship between enterprises and their workers.
>

> Moreover, unlike what happens in biology, h can produce a feedback  into 8. As we shall see, this feedback is of considerable historical impor-  ance. The simplest case occurs when a technique is discovered serendipi-  ously and the fact that it works is registered into the realm of 8. The  growth of 8 might then be further stimulated by this addition, since it is  often provoked by new and unexplained phenomena, including the  operation of a new technique. But changes in techniques also open up new  opportunities, and technical developments in instruments and laboratory  methods make new research possible. Finally, technological success  inspires confidence in the B-knowledge underlying the techniques. This  leads to further expansion of the epistemic base and to improvements and  extensions of the techniques. The historical development of this mutual  reinforcement between 8 and h differs from case to case, but at least since  the middle of the nineteenth century there has been a gradual if incomplete  shift toward a priority of 8.

## 3395. The driving force behind progress was not just tha
> The driving force behind progress was not just that more was known,  but also that institutions and culture collaborated to create better and  cheaper access to the knowledge base. Technology in the nineteenth  century co-evolved with the new institutions of industrial capitalism. Instit-  utional evolution in many ways followed its own dynamic. For instance,  the repeal of the Bubble Act in 1825 was in large part the result of a power  struggle between parties that believed they stood to gain from it (Harris,  2000). The creation of modern management ran into endless difficulties as  documented in the late Sidney Pollard's still unsurpassed classic (Pollard,  1965). Yet on balance the feedback from technology to institutions was  positive. Useful knowledge, like all evolutionary systems, is charac-  terized by the fact that current choices determine future options because of  the tendency of new knowledge to emerge from existing knowledge. This  possibility occurs when a new technology is initially adopted, but  subsequently some new information emerges or some change in  preferences occurs that makes people change their minds. The very nature  of new technological information is that it is irreversible; once learned, it  is difficult if not impossible for society to "unlearn" a new technique, no  matter how socially undesirable. This kind ofphenomenon might be called  the Pandora Effect. Even if society "regrets" its decision to move to T, it  may not be able to return to T, If this process is anticipated, even in  probability, at time 0, it is possible that society may decide not to adopt T, "so that we do not regret it later." This is especially the case with tech-  nology that can be used for both constructive and military purposes, or  which are suspected to lend themselves to some form of political or social  manipulation. Certain inventions that misfired badly have led to difficult  debates such as the current debates on pesticides, cloning, nuclear power,  and genetically modified organisms.

> industry was in any sense induced. All the same, using the framework  proposed in chapter 1, three different "inducement" mechanisms can be  distinguished. First, the growth of SZ itself can be influenced by agenda-  setting signals. If a society is deeply concerned about rabies or atmospheric  pollution, it will find ways to steer pure research into related areas rather  than solid-state physics. Curiosity alone might not account for that; there  are rewards, monetary and others, that create this bias. This kind of activity  takes place in "Pasteur's quadrant" (Stokes, 1997). Of course, if the people  who expand SZ-knowledge are themselves involved in the mapping of their  insights onto h,  this bias is almost automatic.  Second, given a certain Q, prices and similar signals will send  inventors, engineers and technicians to scour the existing bodies of  propositional knowledge for guidance on how to create new combinations  and mappings in order to solve high-priority items and create new  techniques. This is what Stokes calls "Edison's quadrant," which seeks to  apply existing knowledge, not to expand the epistemic base itself (1997, p.  74). The activation of dormant knowledge in SZ seems to be primarily what  "induced innovation" means, though it is rarely fully distinguished from  the induced growth of Q.  Third, relative costs and prices determine which elements of h will be  selected, that is, which technique will be in use (in other words, what is  actually produced and how). Whereas at first glance this choice is little  more than standard substitution, this selection process too could impart a  direction on technological change. Given that experience and learning-by-  using tend to generate "local" improvements in given techniques, at least  up to a point, this kind of mechanism could explain a great deal of what  appears to be "induced" innovation (David, 1975).

> Logo is more than a programming language. It is a learning environment where children explore mathematical ideas and create projects of their own design. Logo, the first programming language explicitly designed for children, was invented by Seymour Papert, Wallace Feurzeig, Daniel Bobrow, and Cynthia Solomon in 1966 at Bolt, Beranek and Newman, Inc. (BBN). Logo’s design drew upon two theoretical frameworks: Jean Piaget’s constructivism and Marvin Minsky’s artificial intelligence research at MIT. One of Logo’s foundational ideas was that children should have a powerful programming environment. Early Lisp served as a model with its symbolic computation, recursive functions, operations on linked lists, and dynamic scoping of variables. Logo became a symbol for change in elementary mathematics education and in the nature of school itself. The search for harnessing the computer’s potential to provide new ways of teaching and learning became a central focus and guiding principle in Logo language development. It encompassed a widening scope that included natural language, music, graphics, animation, story telling, turtle geometry, robots, and other physical

## 3453. his section of the paper is focused on describing
> his section of the paper is focused on describing technical decisions about Logo as a language. Logo is, first of all, a dialect of Lisp. Its original authors were Lisp users at MIT and BBN; since the idea was that Logo would be a language for manipulating (human) language, Lisp’s emphasis on symbolic programming seemed like a great match. In retrospect, this choice was by far the most important aspect of Logo’s design, mainly because of Lisp’s interactive development model, next because of the use of recursion as the main control structure, and third because of Lisp’s support for symbolic computing.
>

## 3454. Pavel Boytchev’s meticulously researched Logo Tree
> Pavel Boytchev’s meticulously researched Logo Tree Project [Boytchev 2014] lists just over 300 dialects of Logo, most but not all of which trace their ultimate ancestry to the 1968 BBN PDP-1 Logo. Some of the listed dialects are Logo in name only, restricted to a turtle graphics library. This section makes no effort to include the details of every dialect; we follow the two main branches of the tree: those descended from Terrapin Logo (based originally on the MIT Logo Group’s version for the Apple II computer) and those descended from the Logo Computer Systems, Inc. (LCSI) dialect of Logo (starting with Apple Logo). Several people worked in both groups at different times.

## 3455. In this paper the history of Logo is divided into
> In this paper the history of Logo is divided into two periods. The dividing line is around 1980. By then the personal computer revolution had started and Papert’s book Mindstorms [Papert 1980] came out. Logo moved from time-shared computers to personal ones. This section highlights some of the key events and ideas from before 1980. Logo was invented in 1966 primarily by Papert and Feurzeig at BBN in Cambridge, Massachusetts. While research continued at BBN under the direction of Feurzeig, in 1969 the Logo Group was started at the MIT AI Lab, a lab that Papert co-directed with Minsky. In the early 1970s a Logo research and development group was formed at University of Edinburgh’s AI Department.
>
> `(SHK+History20|31); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[SHK+History20]] Solomon et al - 2020 - History of Logo.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:16:57`

## 3457. In 1966 Seymour Papert consulted for Wally Feurzei
> In 1966 Seymour Papert consulted for Wally Feurzeig, head of the education group at BBN. Wally had a school project involving five schools. As part of their math class the students were learning a version of Telcomp, an algebraic programming language similar to BASIC. Seymour visited the classrooms and was struck by the absurdity of using an algebraic programming language to help students to understand algebra. Seymour decided that what was needed was a programming language specifically designed for children.

## 3463. on words and sentences, with numbers being special
> on words and sentences, with numbers being special words. But based on work with Minsky and Piaget, Papert was again struck by an expanded view of domains for children’s explorations. What if there were a concrete object to play with? A device that could be controlled by a child? In England William Grey Walter had built Elmer and Elsie, two automatons, that could walk around a space. He called them tortoises. Picking up on Elsie and Elmer, the Logo creatures were dubbed turtles. The early turtles were tethered. They soon had a counterpart living on a graphics screen, initially known as display turtles.

## 3464. 4.2.4 1973ś76: Button Boxes and Slot Machines. Rad
> 4.2.4 1973ś76: Button Boxes and Slot Machines. Radia Perlman, an undergraduate student at the Logo Group in the 1970s, was interested in preschool-age children [Perlman 1974], for whom both the small keyboard buttons on a computer terminal and the need to read and write code were barriers to using Logo. She designed several preschool-specific control devices, of which two were implemented: first the button boxes and then the slot machine [Perlman 1976].
>

## 3465. 4.3.1 Anthropomorphization and Body Syntonics. A c
> 4.3.1 Anthropomorphization and Body Syntonics. A central theme in Papert’s thinking about how children learn about topics such as computers, mathematics, or even their own thinking and learning, is that we understand things in relation to our own bodies. In contrast, traditional school geometry, for example, views the world or the plane from a bird’s eye view: the X and Y axes represent an absolute coordinate system that is foreign to the child. Instead, the natural perspective for a child is to think of what the child wants the turtle to do, in relative terms. To devise or debug a Logo program, the child can łplay turtle.ž Turning left, from the turtle’s eye view, might be turning North, or it might be West, or Southeast, in a traditional coordinate system. When the child łbecomes the turtle,ž there is no confusion as to what turning left means. In his later work, Papert used the phrase Body Syntonics to extend this idea. Anthropomorphization is related, but not identical. The child can imagine how the turtle is deciding what to do, by thinking of it as a little person, or (in the case of subprocedures or recursion, see łlittle man modelž in the next section) a set of people who are asking one another to perform certain steps. Conversely, anthropomorphization allows the child to think, łthe turtle has a bugž rather than łI made a mistake,ž thereby focusing on the intellectual challenge, rather than the negative emotions of the situation. The child uses computation as a helpful metaphor for understanding their own thinking, and even for empathy with the thinking and confusions of others.
>
> `(SHK+History20|40); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[SHK+History20]] Solomon et al - 2020 - History of Logo.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:16:58`

## 3466. 4.3.2 Metalanguage. The goal of Logo was more than
> 4.3.2 Metalanguage. The goal of Logo was more than simply developing a programming language for children. Perhaps equally important was to develop a łmetalanguagež: a collection of metaphors, a vocabulary, and a way of talking both about the language and about the powerful ideas it embodied.
>
> `(SHK+History20|40); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[SHK+History20]] Solomon et al - 2020 - History of Logo.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:16:58`

## 3467. 4.3.3 Debugging. Logo did provide tools to help wi
> 4.3.3 Debugging. Logo did provide tools to help with the debugging of code, when we talk about debugging as a big idea, we’re thinking more about a child debugging his or her understanding of the computing process and of the algorithm that the Logo program should implement. For example, a common beginner’s misunderstanding is to think that the left and right commands move the turtle leftward or rightward on the screen, rather than turning it. A Logo teacher seeing a child struggling with this problem is likely to suggest that the child stand up, move into an unobstructed area in the room, and łplay turtle,ž carrying out the instructions to draw a square, the universal first Logo exercise. When the child’s leg muscles understand the turning commands, that’s the time to return to the computer and revisit the misbehaving code. In the early days, Logo teachers were careful to say łthe turtle has a bug,ž rather than the child or the program having a bug. In playing turtle, the child’s task is to teach the turtle, the child’s relationship with the turtle becomes more like a teacher’s relationship to a learner.
>
> `(SHK+History20|41); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[SHK+History20]] Solomon et al - 2020 - History of Logo.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:16:58`

## 3468. 4.3.4 Procedurization. Converting a set of steps i
> 4.3.4 Procedurization. Converting a set of steps into a named procedure is one of the most powerful ideas a child can learn from a short exposure to Logo. It enables the child to use abstraction, one of the łbig ideasž in adult Computer Science, without needing a formal understanding of this concept. ithout knowing phrases such as łmanaging complexity,ž a child can break down the steps to solve a hard problem into simpler subprocedures, and, significantly, give each procedure a name. Each can be debugged separately, and then used repeatedly.. The usefulness of procedurization increases as the child learns to generalize by providing inputs, such as to parameterize the size of a polygon to be drawn.
>
> `(SHK+History20|42); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[SHK+History20]] Solomon et al - 2020 - History of Logo.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:16:58`

## 3475. In November 1982, Cynthia Solomon†19 visited The B
> In November 1982, Cynthia Solomon†19 visited The Bank Street School, where Roy Pea and Midian Kurland were conducting their studies. Solomon had the opportunity to observe the class- room. They were working with children 11-12 years old. Two teachers had prepared for teaching Logo by attending a three-week workshop. Teachers and children were using three different Logo implementations on two different types of computers, with various feature differences. One of the teacher handouts given to the children for instruction contained several bugs, noticed by some of the children. The main conclusion of the study was that teaching children Logo did not help children learn broader skills such as planning.

> How does the teacher in a Logo classroom feel about the rest of the school, as an institution? And how does the school, as an institution, support or discourage student-centered learning? > In 1972, Ershov was invited to give a prestigious key speech at the American Joint Computer Conference in Atlantic City. The resulting “Aesthetics and the Human Factor in Programming” became his most well-known text, addressing questions that remained pertinent throughout the 1970s and to this day: How should software projects be organized? How should programmers be trained? What individual qualities should be sought and cultivated in programmers?37 In the wake of the so-called software crisis, or the realization that the costs and failure risks associated with software were growing exponentially, Ershov called upon society to recognize and appreciate programming, and upon program- mers to take upon themselves a sense of weighty social responsibility.38 In a nutshell, the “human factor” was the programmer and the “aesthetics” was his aspiration to achieve a perfect combination of program and machine.

In launching the  campaign, Mao highlighted three problems-bureaucracy (guanliao zhuyi ), sectarian ism (zongpai zhuyi ), and subjectivism (zhuguan zhuyi ). In the Chinese Communist lexicon ,  bureau­cracy referred to cadres concentrating power in their own hands, sectarian ­ism referred to cadres alienating themselves from those who were not in the party, and subj ectivism referred to cadres making decisions  based on narrow knowledge and considerations. All three problems were perennial concerns that Mao had made the targets of previous party rectification campaigns. T his time, however, the prescribed methods were different. ## 3524. Because this book does not delve into biography or
> political control. 58 Because this book does not delve into biography or the de­tails of el ite party pol itics, I cannot arbitrate between these interpretations. Ifwe consider the events of 1957 in light of the persistent conflicts over political and cultural power during the Mao Zedong era, however, three general obser­vations can be made. First, the bureaucratic power of party officials-which Mao made a target of the 1957 Party Rectification campaign-was a problem he returned to again and again, each time with greater virulence. By soliciting unsupervised criticism by intellectuals, Mao opened the way for a much more profound discussion of this problem than would have been possible had the party been asked to rectify itself. Second, Mao was completely unsympathetic with intellectuals' conviction that their expertise made them more fit to run the country than the Communists, and much of the most hosti le invective directed against intellectuals during the Anti-Rightist campaign reflected his thinking. T hird, Mao was a master of Machiavellian manipulation of conten­tious political forces for his own ends, and he was probably not dismayed by the sharp conflicts between new and old elites produced by the Party Rectifi­cation campaign. T hese points, however, can only be ful ly discussed once the dramatic events that unfolded a decade later, during the Cultural Revolution, are brought under scrutiny. ## 3630. 半了 ， 因此 ， 有了方案 ， 再建立电脑应用与
维修服务公司就方便得多。最后 ， 也是最重

> 半了 ， 因此 ， 有了方案 ， 再建立电脑应用与 维修服务公司就方便得多。最后 ， 也是最重 要的一环 ， 便是要大力宣传 ， 教育群众懂得 有关电脑的知识和应用 ， 使人们认识到掌握 应用电脑的重要性， 特别是电脑应用实例 ， 因为西方国家在提倡应用时最大的阻力是来 自 “人 ” ， 而非来自 “ 物 ” 。所以， 怎样去 推广电脑教育就很蜇要了。， 邓小平同志曾在上海提出： “普及电子 计算机知识 ， 要从娃娃抓起。” 这一方向是 对的 ， 而娃娃们应首先学些什么电脑知识？ 如何去培训娃娃和小、中学生？这是一个很 现实的问题。 在祖国 ， 订出了方案 ， 工业渐渐落实后 不妨参考国外电脑教育的方法和教材内容 ， 笔者曾将外国的经验作过研究 ， 美国在教育 方面的电脑应用可分为两方面 ， 即学校行政 方面的电脑应用和教学方面的电脑应用 。 教 学方面的电脑用又分为 “ 电脑认识 ” 和 “电 脑科学"' "电脑认识 ” 是从幼儿院开始 ， 一直到高中毕业 ， 基本上是要求学生有能力 示范并了解计算机的应用功能， 以至计算机 技术的震要性 ， 讲授课程要达到四个主要目 的： （一）学生能够在计算机或其它电子设 备上操作时采取适当的应对。 （二）学生能 解释计算机系统和功能。 （三）学生能采用 有系统式的方法用以解决问题。（四）学 生能认识计算机技术对人类生活的冲击。 “电脑科学 ” 是从初中开始至高中毕业的专 门课程 ， 基本上是要求学生有能力去示范和 了解计绊机系统： 包括软件开发 ， 硬件设计 和操作 ， 利用计算机系统解决有关问题。讲 授课程主要要求达到三个目的 一一一 、 学 生编写有结构程式的计算机软件及其详细 说明。 二、 学生了解一 些关于计算机硬件 的设计和操作知识。 三、运用计算机系 统来解决间题。 有 关 “ 电脑认识 ” 和 “电脑科学” 的各年级学习过程 ， 请参阅泭 只要从今天起有计划和按程序教育我们 的下一代 ， 到了二十世纪末 ， 中国便可以有 一代对电脑有所认识的年青人 ， 可以在工业 革命中起到一定的作用。 现今 ， 还没有一种比较满意的适合千教 育的应用的电脑系统， 怎样设计一个适合我 国教育界需要的教学电脑系统呢？ 这样一个系统 ， 笔者认为应该合乎四个 基本原则： （ 一 ）合乎经济原则。 我国的 底子薄 ， 要支付每个中小学一个理想的教学 电脑系统谈何容易 ， 所以一定要合乎经济原 则 ， 价格越低越好。（二）容易管理课堂 秩序。一个老师在课堂上要应付十组学生 ， 每组有一 台微型电脑 ， 如果没有一个合理的 管理系统 ， 就很难控制课堂气氛和秩序。 （三）丰富软件。有了系统 ， 如果没有应用 软件 ， 这系统使用不上去。 （四）中小学的 系统非常需有汉字处理， 否则很难发挥教学 上应用。 笔者作了很多调查研究 ， 发觉世界上现 今还没有一 个国家及其工厂有比较合理的系 统适合我国电脑教育上的应用。 笔者根据自 己的科研成果， 巳经基本上设计出 一 台合乎 上面所提的四项原则 ， 现正与武汉 “ 南湖智 能开发联合公司 ” （国务院武汉区试点）， 共同研制此系统(HW—100号）， 相信短期 内可以做出成果 ， 这样就可以为国家节省一 些外汇 ， 为教育下一代提供有利条件。 展望将来 9 如果整个数学电脑系统的全 部元件都可以在国内提供的话 ， 这样我们就 可以将这样的系统推销到第三世界， 与这些 国家共享 “提倡电脑教育 ” 的经验 ， 并赚外 汇以支持我国在教育界发展电脑教育。 总的来说 ， 国家领导人能够领会电脑应 用的重要性是件好事 ， 但要落实这样的一件 事也不是“一就而就” 的 ， 不能以大锣大鼓 的方式去进行 ， 应以实事求是 ， 有计划按比 例地去发展和推广应用 ， “大炼钢铁” 并不 浪费太多的外汇 ， 这次 “热潮 ” 如果处理不
>

## 3648. {[F-53480ed6-Quote]([P-09409762-ComputerEducation]
> 为 什 么 从 BASIC 入手 呢 ？ 因 为 在 各 种 高级 语 言 中 ， BASIC 是 比 较 容 易 学 井 且 又 有 一 定 实 用 价 值 的 一 种。 BASIC 是 1 964 年 研 制 成 功 的， 是从 FORTRAN 语 言 中 提炼而来， 专 为 初学者设计 的 一种计 算机语言。 它 出 现后， 得 到 各 国 的 普 遍 欢 迎井迅速推广。 目 前， 全 世 界 使 用 BASIC 的 计 算机 已 超 过 了 100 万 台 。 BASIC 有 以下 几 个 特 点 ： ( 1 ) 简 单 易 学 。 只 要 具 有 高 中 文 化 程 度 的 都能 通 过短 时 间 的 学 习 （一般听课时 问 约 为 二 十至三十小时） 掌捏 其基 本 内 容， 有 的 国 家 甚至 已 试验 在 初 中 学 习 BASIC。 BASIC 语 言 中 用 到 的 英 文 词 汇 比 较 少， 很 容 易 记忆， 我 国 具 有 高 中 文 化 程 度 的 人 何 止 千 百 万 ， 这 就 为 BASIC 的 普及提供 了 极 为 广 泛 的 群众基础。 ( 2 )  BASIC 语 言 一 般 采 用 解 释 执 行 方 式 ， 具 有人 机 对 话功能， 上机操作简单， 调 试程序方 便， 很容易检究 错 误 和 修 改 a 它 不 像 FORTRAN 和 COBOL 等程序盂 要 经过 编 辑 、 编 译 、 联接 才能运行这样繁多的操作步 骤。 BASIC 的 这 种 特 点 ， 对 初 学 者 尤 感 便 利 。 ( 3 ) 国 内 外 儿 乎 所 有 的 小 型 和 微 型 计 算机 以 及 一 些 中 型 机 （ 指 通 用 机） 都 配 备 有 BASIC 语言。 在 我 国 现 有 的 计 算机 中 ， 小 型 机 和 微型 机 占 绝 大 多数， 近 儿 年， 我 国 许 多 单 位购 置 了 微型 计 算机， 这就 为 BASIC 的推 广 应 用 创 造 了 很 好 的 物质 条 件 。 如 果 充 分 利 用 的话， 一 台 微 型 计 算 机 一 个 月 可 以 轮 训六十人左右 （ 以 二 人 为 一组， 每组上机时 问 为 10 小 时 计 算 ） 。 微型机价格相 对 便 宜 （最低档 的 约 为 人 民 币 四 于元 ） ， 中 学 也 有 可 能 逐 步 配 置 。 ( 4 )  BASIC 是具有 一 定 实 用 价 值 的 语言， 尤共是不少计算机厂家配备的扩展 BASIC, 有 较 强 的 功能， 不 仅能进行 科 学 计 算， 而且 还 适 于 作 事 务 管 理， 如 统计工资、 成 绩 管 理 、 诊 断 疾 病 等 等。 国 内 许多 单 位 的 同 志 在 短 期 学 习 BASIC ( 很 多 是 收 看 电 视 进 行学 习 的 ） 后， 马上付诸 实 践 ， 编 制 应 用 程序， 取 得 了 显著效果。 清 华 大 学 图 书 馆 工 作 人 员 自 己 动 手 用 BASIC 语言编写 了 图 书检索 程 序和 图 书 流通 管 理程序， 已 正式鉴定通过， 广东 省 中 山 图 书馆 用 BASIC 语 言 编 制 了 “ 读 者 阅 读 倾 向 统计分析程序 ” ， 用 计 算机统计分析读者提交的 索 书 条， 掌 握 读 者 的 阅 读需 要； 南 京 衣 学 院 用 BASIC 编 写 了 一些 农 业方 面 的 应用 程 序， 如计算最佳饲 料配比、 最佳施肥 方 案 选 择 ， 衣 作物 轮 作 的 最佳方案， 劳 动 力 的最佳调配方 法 的 线性规划 求 解程 序， 等等。 许 多 非 计 算 机 专 业 的 科 技 人 员 （ 如医 生 、 农 业科技人 员 、 企业管理人员 … ） 都感到用 BASIC 语言方便有 效， 学 了 马 上 能 用 。 用 了 马 上 能 出 成果。 甚至取得了某些 突 破 性 的 成果。 ( 5 )  BASIC 语 言 可 以 作 为 学 习 其它 计算机语言和计贷机 知 识 的 第 一个台阶。 事 实 证 明 ， 学 习 了 BASIC 后 不少 同 志 破除 了 对 计 算 机 的 神 秘 感， 培 养 了 对计 算 机 的 兴 趣 ， 掌握 了 程序设计 的 基 本 方 法， 在需要时进 一 步 学 习 其 它 语 江 ( FORTRAN, COBOL . .  , ) 不会 感 到 有 什 么 困 难。 “ ”
>

> 同学们应根据本课程特点确定复习方 法。 本课程不是纯理论的课程， 没有太多的 数学推导和理论验证，它是计算机应用课程， 实践性很强， 学习本门课是要学会编写程序 以解决工作中的实际问题， 因此复习中切不 要死记硬背，而要融会贯通，知其所以然。 应 用程序有多种多样， 对同 一 问题可以编写出 不同的程序，由于复习时间较紧，不要求在这 期问阅读其它参考书特，复习时要认真看书， 对重点内容反复领会， 对重点程序自己独立 一

## 3661. 自动编程是自动化语言编程的简称。 所谓自动编程， 简单地说， 就是用某种专用的数控
语言直观地描述
> 自动编程是自动化语言编程的简称。 所谓自动编程， 简单地说， 就是用某种专用的数控 语言直观地描述出零件形状和刀具相对于零件的加工路线顺序和其它工艺参数， 得出用该种 语言写成的加工程序单一一 ”源程序飞然后按规定代码将它穿成信息纸带输入电子计算机，计 算机根据事先配置好的 ”编译程序 “ 将源程序翻译并编辑后自动地进行全部计算， 再由联机的 快速穿孔机自动地制作出控制数控机床加工零件用的控制纸带。 同时， 可打印出数控机床加 工程序单。 必要时， 可在计算机上对制作的控制纸带进行校验，或通过X-Y绘图仪绘制出零 件的轮廓或刀具中心轨迹， 达到检验目的。

>

> 一、计算机思维的定义和历史 计 算 机 思 维 不 是 一 个 新 概 念。 在 1980 年，Seymour  Papert，一个在人工智能领域的前沿学者，用这个术语来预测 孩子们在 1980 年早期将如何学习计算机。计算机思维包括识 别模式和序列，创建算法，设计用于查找和修正错误的测试， 将一般情况集中到精确，并将准确率扩展到一般。计算机思维 有很多种定义，计算思维是一种思维过程，它涉及到制定一个 问题并用计算机或机器能够有效地执行它的解决方案。 计算思维的历史至少可以追溯到 20 世纪 50 年代，但大多 数思想都更古老。计算思维的术语是由 Seymour Papert 在 1980 第一次使用，又在 1996 被第二次使用。计算思维可以用算法 解决大规模的复杂问题规模，从而大幅度提高效率。计算思维 是计算机科学界的前沿，是每个人的基本技能，而不仅仅是计 算机科学家的技能，将计算思想融入其他学科是十分重要的。
>

## 3727. {[F-19d7e003-FACT]([P-a4de272f-SectionII][P-094097
> Currently, computer courses in China emphasize programming in BASIC. The  teachers tried to determine the best age (or grade) for offering an optional com-  puter course. Since the syllabus includes concepts such as function, variable, array,  etc., the course is appropriate for senior high students. Furthermore, the BASIC  language is written in English, so students need to know enough English to use the  language. In addition, schools that have computer courses offer extracurricular ac-  tivities for students interested in working on computers. Obviously, it is unneces-  sary to set a single curriculum for all grades. The purpose and objectives of the  course should match the needs of the students.  A few schools taught Logo to 12- to 14-year-old students instead of BASIC.  Teachers believe that Logo is easier to use than BASIC for these students. Also,  many believe that Logo helps overcome the technology phobia of very young  children. However, the teachers did identify some problems. Recently, a controlled  experiment in teaching Logo was conducted in our experiment center.  An important issue concerns the necessity of learning English before learning  programming. Some teachers tried teaching Logo in Chinese Pin Ying instead of  English. This is a good idea and the results seem positive. It is too early to make a  precise evaluation.
>
> `(QiComputer88|5); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[QiComputer88]] Qi - 1988 - Computer education in secondary schools in the people's Republic of China.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:17:43`

## 3776. At Provincial level, policy on computers in school
> At Provincial level, policy on computers in schools has been developed, too. We looked  particularly at Beijing City, which has provincial status, and Zhejiang Province, the  capital of which is Hangzhou. Beijing, the national capital and an industrial centre, has  a population of about 8 million, and Zhejiang, a comparatively rich agricultural  province on the eastern seaboard, has about 70 million people. Both Beijing and Zhejiang Province have primary schools, junior secondary schools (ages 12-1 5) and senior secondary schools (ages 16-18). Provision of computers is focussed on the  secondary schools, particularly the senior ones, in some of which computer studies are already compulsory. We were fortunate in having top-level contacts in both Beijing and Zhejiang, which make an interesting contrast.
>
> `(HawComputers90|5); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[HawComputers90]] Hawkridge - 1990 - Computers in Third World schools - the example of China.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:17:45`

## 3792. {[F-19d7e003-FACT]([P-a4de272f-SectionII][P-094097
> The picture had changed since computers first arrived in the schools. At first, people  were sceptical, and rather ignorant, about computer studies. Some principals thought  that since other schools had computers, they should too, lest parents complain. A few  did not care about computers at all. Some bureaucrats said that computers were not  needed in a country like China with a large workforce. At the time of our visit, the  Bureau took the view that the economic future depends on young people acquiring  computer knowledge and skills, but because computer studies was not a subject in the  university entrance examinations, some principals still did not recognise the need for it.  Some declared that they were not receiving sufficient money from the Bureau, others  had successfully sought funds for hardware arid software. Principals’ views were  perhaps influenced by the fact that university departments of computer science in  Beijing were in favour of computer studies at school, although a few lecturers were not.  One teacher suggested that principals should be the first to be taught to use computers,  because then they would promote them.
>
> `(HawComputers90|8); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[HawComputers90]] Hawkridge - 1990 - Computers in Third World schools - the example of China.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:17:46`

Teachers  of other subjects often resented the intrusion of computer studies into teaching time in  secondary school. This was understandable against a background of students’ fierce  competition for high examination scores and admission to university.
>

## 3808. {[E-f5f1fdf7-Software]([P-a4de272f-SectionII][P-09
> When the ZPEC allocated computers, it sent each school an Apple I1 clone, with two  operating systems (DOS 3.3 and CP/M) and Logo software. In addition, each school had  to buy its own software. For example, one secondary school bought four programming  languages (FORTKAN-80, Pascal, COBOI, and FORTH-79). plus the STC 2.0 operating  system. It also bought computer-assisted learning packages to help older students to  prepare for the university entrance examination in mathematics, and younger students  to review chemistry and do English exercises. Its applications packages included dBase  11, Wordstar and Multiplan, plus software for personnel file administration, data  management, library management, and a student data management information  system. Finally, it had games packages on fencing, international chess, Chinese chess,  bridge, music, bowling and arcade games. Some of the software was in Chinese, and  some was written at the school.
>

## 3813. {[E-df0064d6-Teacher]([P-a4de272f-SectionII][P-094
> vacation, the ZPEC sent all teachers who had been selected to teach computer studies to  Hangzhou, on a course on principles of computers and software design taught by  Zhejiang and Hangzhou IJniversity staff. Those who passed the final examination  received a certificate. Prior to this course, various training courses had been available  through universities and other agencies. Teachers could go on a course at an  appropriate level if they could get permission from their schools and pay the fees. For  example, first three and then another six teachers were sent from Hangzhou No 4  Middle School, but out of these only two actually became teachers of computer studies.  Another two from this school went, through their own efforts and with the school’s  permission, to the Hangzhou Branch of the Zhejiang Medical University to study the  operating system of IBM PCs, dBase I1 and other software. Teachers from elsewhere in  the province went as far afield as Beijing Normal University or Shanghai East China  Normal [Jniversity, but others went to local universities, colleges or computer centres  for training.

## 3814. {[F-53480ed6-Quote]([P-a4de272f-SectionII][P-09409
> Computer studies was usually an optional course in Zhejiang. Each school chose for it  those students that excel in science and are quick in thinking, because teachers  consider that software design requires precise logical thinking as well as creativity.  Students need to understand the theory underlying BASIC. Some teachers believe that  learning BASIC uniquely develops students’ powers of problem-solving. The core of  program design is the ‘sequence‘, which demands of students a clear understanding of  logical relations. All schools taught BASIC, using any of 20-odd textbooks on it: only a  few have clubs where Logo was taught. Zhejiang teachers told us that Logo  programming may improve students’ ability to think about constructing mathematical  diagrams. Some teachers thought it is more interesting and easier to grasp than BASIC,  especially the geometric parts which may be tackled without arithmetic: they suggested  that Logo is therefore more suitable for primary schools and junior secondary schools.  Others suggested a progression from Logo in primary school to BASIC in junior  secondary school and on to Pascal in senior secondary school.
>
> `(HawComputers90|11); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[HawComputers90]] Hawkridge - 1990 - Computers in Third World schools - the example of China.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:17:46`

## 3818. quality varied widely. Teachers reported a few sim
> quality varied widely. Teachers reported a few simulation programs designed by  students: for example, a student at a Ningbo school developed a prize-winning physics  simulation. Students at another school developed simulations of the laws of conserva-  tion of energy and other physics topics. Other schools developed software for teaching  aspects of physics and electricity, foreign languages and mathematics. Teachers’  attitudes towards program-writing varied: some felt it is very time-consuming to  prepare such software, particularly if it is to be of good quality, and the work is over and  above teachers’ normal workload. They felt that a software centre should be  established, from which teachers should be able to borrow software or copy the  programs as needed. Only in this way will greater efficiency be achieved, with teachers  using their energy for teaching.
>
> `(HawComputers90|12); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[HawComputers90]] Hawkridge - 1990 - Computers in Third World schools - the example of China.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:17:47`

## 3819. Each secondary school with computers had set about
> Each secondary school with computers had set about designing teaching and/or  administrative software to train students and to help the school. At one Hangzhou  school, for example, students had designed several applications packages, under  teacher supervision. One produced statistics from students’ academic records, another  analysed the results of students’ physical examinations, physical education and sports  meetings. At a Ningbo school, students wrote programs to analyse students’  backgrounds and their examination marks, to identify colour-blind students and to  study the composition of sine curves. Elsewhere, students wrote a program simulating  buoyancy, and designed software on principles of the spectrum, on the moving orbit of  particles in magnetic fields, and on graphs. There was no system for distributing such  software, little contact between schools and no discussion of production of standard  programs for widespread use.
>
> `(HawComputers90|12); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[HawComputers90]] Hawkridge - 1990 - Computers in Third World schools - the example of China.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:17:47`

> computers in education. For teaching computer applications, however, they wanted  computers equipped with printers and disc drives, but few had more than one or two at  the time of our visit. As a result, word processing, graphics generation, database use  and similar applications were taught chiefly through computer clubs, where smaller  numbers of students used their spare time to work on the better-equipped computers.  For example, at Putu Middle School, computer club members learned to use dBase 11.  These clubs were also more likely to produce usable programs than the larger computer  studies classes, where more time was spent on theoretical knowledge. In clubs, students  had a better chance to put theory into practice and their interest in computers was  enhanced. As one teacher said, a student who produces a usable program draws the  attention of his parents, his teachers, his principal, the education department and even  the general public, to the value of computers.

There is a  computer program design competition each year, however, and principals were keen to  see their schools winning honours. They also knew that computers can improve school  management. ## 3962. This book attempts to bridge two areas of scholarl
> This book attempts to bridge two areas of scholarly and popular interest. It aims to convince political historians and historians of public administration that they would profit from understanding the history of technology and the material culture of bureaucracy. (Indeed, “bureau” should be put back into studies of “bureaucracy.”) The following points should be highlighted: • The changing capacities of government depended on the implementation f new technologies. • The British Civil Service contained technocratic movements of experts. To ully grasp the implications of this claim requires rejecting the received “neg- tive” historiography of the Treasury. • A distinct solution to the problems of “surveillance” raised by the expanded tate, congruent with articulations of “Britishness,” was enacted. Conversely, this book should provoke historians of science and technology o re-examine the role of government. In particular, it suggests the following: • The uptake of office technology depended on a vision of government, even f it was often commercial business that formed the main market. • The state provided a model of organization so fundamental that consider- tions of “order,” “framework,” “structure,” and “machine” are inextricably inked with understandings of “state” or “government.” This last point can be onsidered as asserting, in its extreme form, that to study the history of tech- ology is to study the state, and vice versa. • The Civil Service, cast as a general-purpose universal machine, framed the anguage of what a computer was and could do.
>

## 3990. The Second World War is often presented, first and
> The Second World War is often presented, first and foremost, as a war of pro- duction in which American and Soviet manufacture of guns, ships, aircraft, and tanks were decisive. The prominent interventions of science, the  Manhattan Project to build atomic weapons or penicillin on the medical front, were also largely achievements of engineering and mass production techniques rather than, say, “pure” science. However, it is the contention of this chapter that the conflict was also an “information” war—although a crude distinction cannot be drawn between the two—not only did the concept of information crystallize in the practical context of warfare, but also a string of new organ- izations emerged to collect, process and distribute it.
>

## 3991. In this chapter the techniques and implications of
> In this chapter the techniques and implications of government information processing in the Second World War are examined. Both radar and crypt- analysis—codebreaking—provide good, and now relatively familiar, examples of how prewar information systems were substantially deepened, expanded and mechanized. These systems were directed against the enemy. However less celebrated techniques on the home front were also transformed, although again by building on pre-1939 precedents: the bureaucracy of identity cards was re-introduced, enabling coordination of rationing, recruitment, and police surveillance, while the techniques of market research and advertising, which were largely a phenomena of private industry before 1939, became key gov- ernment activities with propaganda, the Social Survey, and Mass Observation. It is argued that relatively unsung aspects of government work also changed, with important implications for the planning of war (and after): personnel and stores accounting records on punched cards, for example, allowed machines to keep track of people and objects. Reform in statistics—including the estab- lishment of a Central Statistical Office—took place that, as was noted in chapter 3, proved impossible to achieve a few decades earlier. The calculating capacity of government deepened with the operation of bureaus such as  the Admiralty Computing Service. Wartime developments in planning,

> Why was there such a dramatic increase in the use of information tech- ologies, especially office machinery? First and foremost, the Second World ar presented massive problems of managing highly extended technological ystems. People and matériel had to be organized at immense distances: in the ritish case this network might stretch from Command headquarters in ondon, via the devolved military hierarchy, to tank campaigns in North Africa r anti-U-boat activities in the North Atlantic, and further afield. Moreover, he operation was akin to a planned economy, with the consequence that much f the information processing normally borne by the market had to be done xplicitly. Finally, speed—of decision making, calculation, and data handling n particular—was at a premium. Indeed, the great demand for office machin- ry created severe problems for its British manufacturers, BTM and Powers.99 Indeed, some applications of Hollerith techniques to government work, even within the military, were delayed until after the war because of the apparent scarcity of machines.100 We have already seen that this context led to mechanization, automation, use of electronics, and standardization of communication. The widespread application of punched-card equipment to government work had conse- quences in four areas: for the level of detailed knowledge of the home front, a deepening of the capacity for calculation, and the ability to track objects  and people within the “war machine.”101 An example of the first of these  was the Social Survey, discussed above, which was dependent on teams of Hollerith staff to process its data.102 The following three consequences will be examined in more depth below by focusing on three examples: the Admiralty Computing Service (deepened capacity for calculation), Royal Air Force stores accounting (tracking objects) and RAF personnel organization (tracking people).

## 3999. The Civil Service was a general-purpose “machine”
> The Civil Service was a general-purpose “machine” governed by a code. The stored-program computer is a general-purpose machine governed by a code. Is this similarity a coincidence, or is there a profound connection? I think that the computer is indeed a materialization of bureaucratic action, but the con- nection between the two is far from simple. In particular, the relationship has had to be explored through a historical account of both the articulation of government as a machine and the achievement by social movements of the mechanization of the work of government. So not only have I tried to analyze developments in political thought; I have also sought to give accounts of mech- anization within one of the most extensive (in space and time) organizations. - **It has been the argument of this paper that we should not conflate**

**the history of invention and innovation with the history of technology. This is not, I insist, an original point. It has been made many**

**times, as I have shown. But it has been ignored again and again, with**

**very unfortunate results for our understanding of the relations of**

**technology and society. The history of technology is too important to**

**be left to the historians of invention, or their modern equivalents.**

**This paper has been unoriginal in another way: for a long time writers on technology have criticised previous writers for methodological confusion, and other vices. But there is a difference: I have**

**tried to show that we already have the intellectual resources at least**

**to clarify many of these problems. The most important is history. We**

**should be in a position to cumulate knowledge, derived from many**

**different traditions, to be aware of alternative forms of understanding, to beware of claims of a one best way, and to remember that we**

**have lived with technology for a very long time.  | ]**

## 4413. 作者说，这样一种，对独立和，隐私的意识，是如此根深蒂固，以至于如果在有选择的情况下，人们总选择一种个
> tural conditions. It is a convention so deeply embedded in our individual and collective consciousnesses that even the profound changes wrought by the twentieth century have not yet shaken it.
>
> `(CowMore85|175); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[CowMore85]] Cowan - 1985 - More Work For Mother - The Ironies Of Household Technology From The Open Hearth To The Microwave2.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:19:40`

- **作者说，这样一种，对独立和，隐私的意识，是如此根深蒂固，以至于如果在有选择的情况下，人们总选择一种个人的稳定的，具有居住模式，选择维护自己的家庭，可以这样的原则，不腐的，改变和趋势获科技进步，都有可能被弃之不顾，**

**[对于这个我有几个问题？第一个是作者如何回应马克思主义的？很重要，因为作者的答案，似乎又回到了一个轮回，一种意识形态，决定了人们作出的固执选择，还是某种物质选择，决定了人们的意识形态，作者是如何回答这个问题的？究竟是一种个人主义，决定了，这些妇女决定，维护家庭和在家庭中，进行劳作，还是说正是因为资本主义的要求，在这样的经济环境下，造成他们必须进行这样的劳作，**

**[第二点，是关于，一个文章中的，分析如何被看待？那就是关于，杨总冰箱的比较，一种是用液化气的冰箱，另一种是使用电力的冰箱，之所以一个最后成功，另一个没有成功，作者是用，他们公司的，不同的经济状况来解释的，但他并没有说，这点究竟如何妨碍了，你则，也就是说那种个人独立的居家意识形态，如何与这样一种选择发生关系，作者，怎么样把这个例子用到他的论点上，这点我没有看清，，**

**[我重新看了一下，似乎作者意思是说，这样的一种现象也同样可以用家庭来解释，所以他们买电冰箱，而不是液化气冰箱，当时电冰箱更便宜，而这种花费，选择一个更好的冰箱，对家庭生活的维系并没有直接的帮助，他们也这两个中发生了关系，也就是说，他们两个的关系，是电冰箱，对家庭关系没有产生举足轻重的作用，所以，家庭的结构并没有影响人们对电冰箱的选择，所以在这个方面，电冰箱的胜出，更多的还是商家的结果，**

**[但难道这不是一个，非常武断的选择出发点的问题吗？如果我们已经选择用家庭结构来说明这一切的问题，那我们为什么还要去分析，这样的事情呢？可以把所有的事情都看作，适应和不适应我确定的某种意识形态，那对于适应的我们就说，他扶住了她，对于不适用的例如电冰箱的选择，对家庭没有影响，我们就说，他们之间没有关系，或，他们没有被他阻碍，但这样的意义并不是很大，**

**[我觉得作者的结论没有，很好的，服务于作者的精彩的分析，他在很多部分的分析，例如各种商业，洗一点，女仆，女工，公经济合作社，等等，都有非常的精到之处，考虑的视角也非常全面，但在最后，在总结阶段，似乎，把它们用某种垄断的方式，结合了起来，并没有给予每一个方面，够的重视，这是我觉得他的一个问题所在**

## 4445. 时频谱，的目的就在于，把升学的转换为视觉的，通过视觉的方式来表现，声音，在人的内耳中所听到的直觉，我
> monitor their own voices. In the twentieth century, sound spectrography  became the primary means for machines to recognize human speech,  through the matching of incoming sound-wave patterns to those in a stored  database.
>
> `(MilDeaf10|4); D:\Dropbox\NEra\New_Core_Reading\[R] [[MilDeaf10]] Mills - 2010 - Deaf Jam - From Inscription to Reproduction to Information.pdf; 2021-11-01 11:19:42`

- **时频谱，的目的就在于，把升学的转换为视觉的，通过视觉的方式来表现，声音，在人的内耳中所听到的直觉，我开始被用作，决定哪一部分的声音是可以省略，哪一部分的声音是必须的！这是出于当时制造电话线路和信息传送的考虑，他们既想要有一个完整性，也就是说使用电话的人感受到自己接受了全部的语音信息，同时要具有经济性，也就是可以把那些不影响语音信息的真实性的，部分消除掉，**

**同时，这种发明被认为可以，帮助聋人，来重新，进入口头交流的是雨，用眼睛来代替耳朵，虽然实际上对于很多人来说，这是无法做到的，其他的方式来待一天里，但当时的想法是认为，通过视觉信息的接收，可以进一步纠正他们自己所发出的声音，所以一个聋人和他的信息源之间就形成了反馈，**

**而这种反馈，以及时频谱作为对声音的一种抽象和捕捉，以及他对通讯科技发明时所起的作用，都成为了后来的信息理论的，一个重要的先驱，如同在今天的语音识别中，正是通过时频谱的方式，来比对机器听到的声音和它储存在数据库中的样本，，**

Chinese today can be written in an  alphabetic text known as Pinyin. but cultural  resistance to Pinyin is massive. and Pinyin  would indeed make impossible the retention  and conveyance o f  the rich layers of multiplex  meanings with which individual Chinese  characters are visually loaded.
